revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:Homelands (''Fables'')}} The '''Homelands''' are the mythical lands from [[fairy tales]], [[folklore]], and [[nursery rhymes]] in the comic book series ''[[Fables (comics)|Fables]]''.<ref name="vert-ency">{{Citation | last = Irvine | first = Alex | author-link = Alexander C. Irvine | contribution = Fables | editor-last = Dougall | editor-first = Alastair | title = The Vertigo Encyclopedia | pages = 72–81 | publisher = [[Dorling Kindersley]] | place = New York | year = 2008 | ISBN = 0-7566-4122-5 | oclc = 213309015}}</ref> The majority of those listed have been conquered by the mysterious [[The Adversary (Fables)|Adversary]], as he has conquered most of the European Fable lands. This is a list of the Homelands that have been directly referenced in ''Fables'' and its spin-offs ''[[Jack of Fables]]'', ''[[Cinderella: From Fabletown with Love]]'', ''Cinderella: Fables are Forever'' and ''[[Fairest (comics)|Fairest]]''.
== Major lands ==
*'''[[Tuscany|Toscane]]'''<ref name="F99">''Fables'' 99: ''Dark City''</ref> – Also known as the Imperial Homeworld.<ref name="H">''Fables: Homelands''</ref> This world is [[Italy|Italian]] in nature, which can be seen in the Roman styles of architecture of '''Calabri Anagni''', the capital city of the Empire.<ref name="H" /> This world is home to several Italian Fables; [[The Adversary (Fables)|the Adversary]]<ref name="H" /> and the characters from the tale of ''[[Pinnochio]]''. Formerly the home [[Sacred grove]],<ref name="H" /> now located in the Kingdom of Haven.<ref>''Fables'' 69: ''The Good Prince'', Chapter Nine</ref> When translated into Latin, ''Calabri'' refers to the Boot heel-shaped peninsula in Italy and ''[[Anagni]]'' refers to the ancient town in central Italy. *'''The Kingdom of the Great Lion''' – A reference to [[Narnia]],<ref>Nevins, Jess, [[Bill Willingham|Willingham, Bill]], [[Mark Buckingham|Buckingham, Mark]] (2013). ''Fables Encyclopedia''. New York. [[DC Comics]]. {{ISBN|978-1-4012-4395-1}}. Page 240</ref> It was another land that was conquered early on.<ref name="F5">''Fables'' 5: ''Legends in Exile'', Chapter Five</ref> Due to the ''[[Chronicles of Narnia]]'' currently being protected by copyright, the kingdom may never be officially named. The first chapter of "War And Pieces" is called "The Voyage Of The Sky Treader",<ref>''Fables'' 73:''War and Pieces'', Chapter One</ref> which may be a reference to ''[[The Voyage Of The Dawn Treader]]'' (the 5th book in the "Narnia" series, using the internal chronology). In ''Fables'' 137 (''Camelot'', Part Six), [[List of Fables characters (New York Fables)#"The Cubs"|Winter]] refers to a book [[Snow White (Fables)|her mother]] reads to her and her siblings all the time, about a land where there is always winter, but never Christmas;<ref name="Fables137">''Fables'' 137: ''Camelot'', Part 6</ref> this is a reference to ''[[The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe]]. *'''[[Middle-Earth]]''' – A flashback in the ''Legends in Exile'' story arc shows short slaves ([[Hobbit]]s) being whipped by [[goblin]]s ([[orc]]s). Yet another land conquered by the Adversary.<ref name="F5" /> *'''[[Lilliput and Blefuscu|Lilliput]]''' – From ''[[Gulliver's Travels]]''; It is unknown if the island of Lilliput is conquered by the Adversary, however, the first party that came from Lilliput is now living in Smalltown of [[Fabletown]]'s upstate Farm annex.<ref name="F18">''Fables'' 18: ''Barleycorn Brides''</ref> *'''Bornegascar''' and '''Madagao''' – From ''Fantastic Fables'' by [[Ambrose Bierce]],<ref>{{cite web |first= |url=http://www.gutenberg.org/files/374/374-h/374-h.htm |title=The Project Gutenberg eBook, ''Fantastic Fables'', by Ambrose Bierce |publisher=Project Gutenberg |date=January 17, 2007 |accessdate= }}</ref> the rival kings managed to escape and died side by side in ''The Last Castle''.<ref name="LC">''Fables: The Last Castle''</ref> *'''The Kingdom of the [[List of Fables characters#The North Wind|North Wind]]''' – Also referred to as "the North".<ref name="ReferenceA">''Fables'' 110: ''Inherit the Wind'', Chapter Three</ref> The lands of the North Wind were not taken, as the Adversary’s minions "knew to leave him alone".<ref name="F43" /> '''Foggytown''' is located in the Kingdom of the North Wind.<ref>''Fables'' 102: ''Super Team'', Chapter One</ref> *'''The Rus''' – A mythical version of [[Russia]]<ref name="F99" /><ref name="PM">''[[Peter and Max: A Fables Novel]]''</ref> and home to many [[Slavic peoples|Slavic]] Fables; [[List of Fables characters#Baba Yaga|Baba Yaga]], the mice and the cat from the Russian [[lubok]] ''[[Lubok|The Mice are burying the Cat]]'',<ref name="F37">''Fables'' 37: ''Homelands'', Chapter Two</ref> and [[Ivan the Fool|Ivan Durak]],<ref name="CF">''Cinderella: Fables Are Forever''</ref> all came from this world. It was controlled by Baba Yaga, until she was captured in the Battle of Fabletown. Her Knights also patrolled the lands until they were beheaded by [[Boy Blue (Fables)|Boy Blue]].<ref name="F37" /> [[List of Fables characters#Other Literals|Prose Page]] spent years in the Rus during her quest for knowledge in the Homelands.<ref name="JOF32">''Jack of Fables 32: The Books of War'', Volume Five</ref> Mundane Russia is approximately one-sixteenth the size of the magical Rus.<ref name="PM" /> *'''Dunhill''', '''Viss''', '''Haven''', and '''Lamien''' – The home of Lumi, the [[List of Fables characters#The Snow Queen|Snow Queen]].<ref>''Jack of Fables'' 6: ''Jack Frost'', Part One</ref> These were not conquered, as Lumi made a deal in which she would use her powers in the Adversary's service, if he would spare her world.<ref>''Fairest'' 04: ''Wide Awake'', Chapter Four</ref> *'''The Arabian Homeworld''' – The Arabic Fable Homeworld.<ref name="F42">''Fables'' 42: ''Arabian Nights (and Days)'', Part One</ref> It is a primary Islamic world<ref name="F42" /> host to places such as '''[[Ali Baba|Ali Baba's Cave]]''',<ref name="F45">''Fables 45: ''Arabian Nights (and Days)'', Part Four</ref> mythical versions of '''[[Baghdad]]'''<ref name="F42" /> and '''[[Samarcand]]''' and '''Fabletown East'''.<ref name="F45" /> [[Flying carpet]]s,<ref name="F45" /><ref name="F46">''Fables'' 46: ''The Ballad of Rodney and June'', Part One</ref> [[Manticores]]<ref name="F46" /> and Ghouls<ref name="C" /> can also be found in this world. A gate to this world is found in modern-day [[Baghdad]], leading to its fabled version.<ref name="F44">''Arabian Nights (and Days)'', Part Three</ref> [[Solomon]]'s plan of trapping [[Djinn]]s in wish-granting bottles was initiated here.<ref name="F43">''Fables'' 43: ''Arabian Nights (and Days)'', Part Two</ref> [[Sinbad]],<ref name="F42" /> Yusuf,<ref name="F42" /> Hakim<ref name="F42" /> and the Three Harem girls,<ref name="F45" /><ref name="C" /> Sidi-Nouman,<ref name="F44" /> King [[List of One Thousand and One Nights characters#Shahryār|Shahryar]],<ref name="F1001" /> [[Scheherazade]],<ref name="F1001" /> [[Aladdin]]<ref name="F45" /> and [[Ali Baba]]<ref name="F45" /> all came from this world. *'''The Cloud Kingdoms''' – From ''[[Jack and the Beanstalk]]'', the Cloud Kingdoms exist in their own interdimensional way, being a world of their own but at the same time existing over all of the other worlds.<ref>''Fables'' 50: ''Happily Ever After''</ref> *'''Thrumbly Warrens''' – A land inhabited by talking rabbits and inspired by ''[[Watership Down]]'', these were shown as being taken in ''[[1001 Nights of Snowfall]]''.<ref name="F1001">''Fables: 1001 Nights of Snowfall''</ref> *'''The Indu''' – A fabled version of [[India]], and home to [[Mowgli]], [[Shere Khan]], [[Bagheera]], [[Baloo]] and others from ''[[The Jungle Book]]''. As the last remaining member of the [[Mughal Raj|Raj]], the current [[Viceroy]] is Lord Mountbatten, a [[Automaton|Clockwork Tiger]] crafted as a gift to Lord Viceroy Lovejoy by the craftsmen of [[Maharaja]] Sindu Baba Singh. The Indu might not be the home to Fables of Indian origin but rather those who are born from the British view on India, thus explaining why it was conquered alongside the European worlds instead of the Oriental worlds.<ref>''Fables: The Dark Ages''</ref> *The '''Golden Realm''' – Also known as '''The West'''. It was ruled by the King to the West, the father of the prince from the fairy tale ''[[Snow White and Rose Red]]''. The Golden Realm borders on the Silver Realm and The North. The '''Magical Forest''' from ''Snow White and Rose Red'' and ''[[Snow White|Snow White and the Seven Dwarves]]'' lies in between all three realms.<ref name="F96">''Fables 96: Rose Red'', Chapter Three</ref> *The '''Silver Realm''' – Also known as '''The East'''. From ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarves''. It was ruled by the [[Queen (Snow White)|Evil Queen]] after her husband, the King to the East, died.<ref name="F96" /> *'''The North''' – The Lands of [[Prince Charming (Fables)|Prince Charming]], ruled by his father, the King to the North.<ref name="F96" /> Prince Charming's lands were confirmed as taken in the ''Legends in Exile'' story arc.<ref name="F4">''Fables'' 4: ''Legends in Exile'', Chapter Four</ref> Whether or not the Adversary conquered the Dwarf Kingdom underneath<ref name="F1001" /> is unknown. However, no dwarves seem to be living in [[Fabletown]], The Farm or even The [[Golden Boughs Retirement Village]]. Furthermore, Dwarf Kingdom was not even mentioned during war preparations. *'''Landfall''' – A [[science fiction]]-like world with advanced technology and [[human space flight|space travel]]. Apparently, Landfall was not conquered by the Adversary. [[List of Fables characters#The New Jack Frost – "Jack Two" or "Jack Too"|"Jack Frost Two"]] spent time there during his career as a hero-for hire. The capital city is also called Landfall.<ref>''Jack of Fables'' 41-45: ''The Fulminate Blade''</ref> *'''[[State of Hesse|The Hesse]]''' – The [[Germany|German]] Fable lands.<ref name="F99"/> The name Hesse is derived from one of the larger states in Germany. The Hesse is host to the '''[[Black Forest]]''', the city of '''[[Hamelin]]''', the town of '''[[Winsen (Luhe)|Winsen]]''' and the '''[[Weser]] River'''.<ref name="PM" /> Much of the novel ''Peter and Max'' is set in Hesse,<ref name="PM" /> and Dunster Happ spent seven years in the Hesse trapping the last of the Baleful Hernes<ref name="F86">''Fables'' 86: ''Boxing Days''</ref> (presumably a reference to [[Herne the Hunter]] and [[Wild Hunt]]). *'''[[Erin]]''' – The mythical version of [[Ireland]].<ref name="PM" /> The name Erin deriving from the Irish name for Ireland “Éirinn". *'''[[Albion]]''' – The Homelands version of [[England]]<ref name="F99"/><ref name="PM" /> It is the home to many English Fables as the name derives from the eldest known name for the [[United Kingdom]]. *'''[[Thule|Ultima Thule]]''' – Seen in the mini-series ''[[Cinderella: From Fabletown with Love]]''. Thule is a Fable homeworld that mainly draws its characters from [[Norwegian Folktales]]. Humans and [[troll]]s live side by side with [[sentience|sentient]] [[moose]], [[fox]]es and [[polar bear]]s. Thule was governed before, during and after the Adversary conquered it by [[White-Bear-King-Valemon|King Valemon]] and his bride until they were overthrown by its current ruler, Cinderella's Fairy Godmother. Night lasts for six months in Ultima Thule.<ref name="C">''Cinderella: From Fabletown with Love''</ref> *'''[[Land of Oz|Oz]]''' – Also known as the '''Emerald Kingdom''', from the classic ''[[The Wonderful Wizard of Oz|Wizard of Oz]]'' series by [[L. Frank Baum]]. It and surrounding kingdoms are controlled by the [[Nome King]].<ref name="F101">''Fables'' 101: ''The Ascent''</ref> The Scarecrow, Tin Man, Lion, and Dorothy were imprisoned at the [[Golden Boughs Retirement Village]] until [[Jack Horner (Fables)|Jack Horner]] helped them escape.<ref>''Jack of Fables: The Big Book of War''</ref> [[Princess Ozma]] escaped and is currently a member of Fabletown's coven of magicians, witches and sorcerers.<ref>''Fables: Witches''</ref> It is revealed that a road is being constructed through the '''[[Deadly Desert]]''' linking Oz properly to surrounding lands and kingdoms.<ref name="F101" /> The '''[[Emerald City]]''' appears in the story arc ''Inherit the Wind''.<ref name="F111">''Fables'' 111: ''Inherit the Wind'', Chapter Four</ref> *'''[[Land of Ev|The Land of Ev]]''' – [[List of Fables characters#Bufkin|Bufkin]] ends up here after climbing the Fabletown Business Office's tree. Ev, like Oz, was conquered by the former Adversary, and is now ruled by the Nome King as part of his Pan-Ozian Empire. While sitting in one of Ev's native Lunch Box Trees, Bufkin accidentally saves [[List of Fables characters#Bungle, the Glass Cat|Bungle the Glass Cat]], [[List of Fables characters#Jack Pumpkinhead|Jack Pumpkinhead]] and [[List of Fables characters#Other Oz-characters|The Sawhorse]] from a couple of "Rumbe Tumble Toms".<ref name="F101" /> *The '''Lands of the West''' – Ruled by the [[List of Fables characters#The West Wind|West Wind]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/> *'''Far Mattagonia'''<ref name="F115">''Fables'' 115: ''Cubs in Toyland'', Chapter Two</ref> – Also known as '''Toyland''',<ref name="F115" /> '''Madland'''<ref name="F115" /> and the '''Wondrous Shore'''.<ref name="F116">''Fables'' 116: ''Cubs in Toyland'', Chapter Three</ref> A land of discarded toys, the Discardia.<ref name="F116" /> Because the land is inhabited by toys from the mundane world,<ref>''Fables'' 118: ''Cubs in Toyland'', Chapter 5</ref> it is possible that Toyland is not actually part of the Homelands, but part of another, alternate reality. *The '''Hidden Kingdom''' – The homelands version of [[Japan]]. The people of The Hidden Kingdom lived side by side with creatures from [[Japanese mythology]], including the [[funayurei|funa yurei]],<ref name="F9">''Fairest'' 09: ''The Hidden Kingdom'', Chapter Two</ref> [[kappa (folklore)|kappa]]s,<ref name="F9" /> the legendary [[Japanese raccoon dog|tanuki]],<ref name="F9" /> [[kitsune]],<ref name="F9" /> [[qilin|kirin]]<ref name="F11">''Fairest'' 11: ''The Hidden Kingdom'', Chapter Four</ref> and assorted [[yokai]].<ref name="F9" /> It was ruled by an [[Emperor of Japan|Emperor]], who is referred to as [[Emperor of Japan|Heika]],<ref name="F9" /> a term used to identify the emperor in [[Japanese language|Japanese]]. The Hidden Kingdom was conquered by the Adversary after the [[shogun|Seii Taishogun]] was secretly laying the way for an invasion.<ref name="F11" /> Many of the kingdom's citizens are living in exile in a secret Fable community in [[Tokyo]].<ref name="F9" /> *The '''[[Roman Empire]]''' – While searching for her lost children, [[List of Fables characters#Rapunzel/Okiku|Rapunzel]] witnessed the birth of an empire, when she found a she-wolf suckling the infant [[Romulus and Remus]].<ref name="Fairest10">''Fairest'' 10: ''The Hidden Kingdom'', Chapter Three</ref> *The '''Kingdom of a Thousand Hills''' – A homeworld of [[Africa]]n origin. One of the many worlds that Rapunzel visited while searching for her lost children.<ref name="Fairest10" /> *'''[[Wonderland (fictional country)|Wonderland]]''', '''[[Looking-Glass Land]]''' and '''[[The Hunting of the Snark|Snark Island]]''' – From [[Lewis Carroll]]'s ''[[Alice in Wonderland]]'' and ''[[Through the Looking-Glass]]''. Never shown or referred to, except for a vague reference to Looking-Glass Land in the "who's who" in the ''[[Jack of Fables]]'' trade paperback ''Jack of Hearts'', which refers to Alice as "a survivor of several adventures through a looking-glass, including a meal of questionable mushrooms". These lands are assumed to have been conquered since numerous playing cards and the [[Cheshire Cat]] are residents of Fabletown.<ref>''Fables 6: Animal Farm'', Chapter One</ref> [[List of Fables characters#Alice|Alice]],<ref>''Jack of Fables 2: The (Nearly) Great Escape'', Part Two</ref> the [[Mad Hatter]], the [[Dormouse (Alice's Adventures in Wonderland)|Dormouse]] and the [[March Hare]],<ref>''Jack of Fables 27: Turning Pages'', Part Three</ref> [[the Walrus and the Carpenter]] (and the oysters they seem not to have eaten yet)<ref>''Jack of Fables 1: The (Nearly) Great Escape'', Part One</ref> were held prisoner at the [[Golden Boughs Retirement Village]]. [[List of Fables characters#Humpty Dumpty|Humpty Dumpty]] is also a prisoner and a violet/pink caterpillar (which may or may not be the [[Caterpillar (Alice's Adventures in Wonderland)|Caterpillar]]) is shown eating a leaf while Humpty Dumpty tries to convince [[Jack Horner (Fables)|Jack Horner]] to let him escape with the others.<ref>''Jack of Fables 3: The (Nearly) Great Escape'', Part Three</ref> The [[Vorpal Sword]] is now Fabletown property, and has been referred to as the [[Jabberwock]]'s bane.<ref>''Fables 3: Legends in Exile'', Chapter Three</ref> This could imply that [[Jabberwocky|Tulgey Wood]] has been conquered as well.
== Places == *'''Keep at the End of the World''' – From ''[[East of the Sun and West of the Moon]]'', this was the setting for ''The Last Castle'', where the last Fable refugees escaped from to the Mundy world.<ref name="LC" /> *'''The [[Black Forest]]''' – Located in the Hesse and former home to [[Bigby Wolf]], [[Frau Totenkinder]] and a whole array of malign spirits, ogres and bogeymen. It is not known whether the Forest itself was taken over by the Empire, because the Hessians themselves do not dare to enter it. The rest of the Hesse, on the contrary, was indeed conquered. In ''[[Peter and Max: A Fables Novel]]'', it is revealed that the Adversary's troops did enter the Black Forests on numerous occasions (to try to hunt The Big Bad Wolf, as well as to travel to Hamelin).<ref name="PM" /> *'''[[Camelot]]''' – Appears in flashbacks in the story arc ''The Good Prince''. According to the [[ghost]] of Sir [[Lancelot]], the legend of Camelot and its fabled [[King Arthur]] set the standard of "true chivalry" for all of [[christendom]] and its legend touched much of the pagan worlds beyond. Lancelot's betrayal would eventually lead to Camelot's downfall.<ref>''Fables'' 62: ''The Good Prince'', Chapter Two</ref> *The '''Kingdom of Haven''' – The home of [[Flycatcher (Fables)|Flycatcher]], they were shown being taken in ''[[1001 Nights of Snowfall]]''.<ref name="F1001" /> Recently, he has returned there with his new army of ghosts and has set it up as a place of refuge for anyone wishing to escape the Adversary's control. He has become a consistent thorn in the Adversary's side, having defeated much of the Adversary's forces, including turning all of the Empire's wooden soldiers into a new enchanted grove, taking out the Empire's best fighters. *'''The Lands of [[List of Fables characters#Beauty and the Beast|Beauty and the Beast]]''' – These are assumed taken because Beast refers to their lands as "forever lost in the Homelands", in the ''Legends in Exile'' story arc.<ref name="F4" /> *'''The Lands of [[King Cole (Fables)|Old King Cole]]''' – These were shown being taken in ''[[1001 Nights of Snowfall]]''.<ref name="F1001" /> *'''The Lands of King Noble''' – From the [[Reynard]] stories, these were shown as captured in ''[[1001 Nights of Snowfall]]''. Reynard helped most of the animals escape the invading forces.<ref name="F1001" /> *'''[[Nottingham]]''' – Directly mentioned as being captured in ''The Last Castle'', it was [[Robin Hood]]'s home.<ref name="LC" /> *'''[[Colchester]]''' – [[List of characters in Fables#Humpty Dumpty|Humpty Dumpty]] from ''[[Jack of Fables]]'' was a [[cannon]] for the Homelands version of the [[Siege of Colchester]].<ref>''Jack of Fables'' 5: ''The (Nearly) Great Escape'', Chapter Five</ref> *'''[[Mr. Toad|Toad Hall]]''' – From ''[[Wind in the Willows]]'', it is directly mentioned as being taken in [[1001 Nights of Snowfall]].<ref name="F1001" /> Badger, Toad and Mole all escaped,<ref name="F1001" /> and many assume Stinky the Badger on the Farm is in fact the same character as Mr. Badger. *'''[[Atlantis]]''' – The underwater kingdom of mermaids was shown being conquered in ''[[1001 Nights of Snowfall]]''. The only known survivor is Mersey Dotes, now turned into a mermaid.<ref name="F1001" /> *'''Red City''' – Mentioned by the Snow Queen. Red City Plague originates from this City.<ref>''Fables'' 53: ''Sons of Empire'', Part Two</ref> Red City Plague might possibly allude to Edgar Allan Poe's ''[[Masque of the Red Death]]''. *'''[[Night on Bald Mountain|Bald Mountain]]''' – From [[Modest Mussorgsky]]'s play. Directly mentioned in ''Jack of Fables''. It is home to Chernobog, one of the Devils Jack made a deal with to prolong his life.<ref>''Jack of Fables'' 16: ''Jack O Lantern''</ref> *'''[[Rome]]''' – The Fabled version of the capital of [[Italy]]. [[Incitatus]] was a member of its senate.<ref>''Jack of Fables'' 23: ''1883'', Chapter Two</ref> *'''The lands of the [[List of Fables characters#Civilized Apes (maybe)|"civilized apes"]]''' – Appear in flashbacks in the ''Jack of Fables'' story ''Jack 'n' Apes''. These lands were conquered by the Adversary's forces.<ref name="JOF36">''Jack of Fables 36: Jack 'n' Apes''</ref> *The '''[[Hundred Acre Wood]]''' – In the ''Jack of Fables'' story ''Jack 'n' Apes'', a character looking remarkably similar to [[Winnie the Pooh]] (but drawn slightly differently, as Winnie the Pooh is currently under copyright) can be seen in flashbacks from the Homelands, barbecuing [[marshmallow]]s with the [[sock monkey]] Saunders in what appears to be the Hundred Acre Wood. They were described as living in "blissful simplicity".<ref name="JOF36" /> In the works of author [[A. A. Milne]], ''Sanders'' is the name of the person who resided at Pooh's home prior to Pooh making it his house,<ref>{{cite web|first=|url=http://www.thelinguist.com/fr/en/library/item/65344/|title=''Winnie The Pooh and All, All, All'' Alan Alexander Milne|publisher=The Linguist|date=|accessdate=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111008204611/http://www.thelinguist.com/fr/en/library/item/65344/|archivedate=2011-10-08|df=}}</ref> and Winnie the Pooh and several other characters from the books were based on the stuffed toys of [[Christopher Robin Milne|Milne's son]]. Saunders and his friends were driven from their homes when the Adversary invaded, and Saunders ended up in [[Africa]] in the mundane world, along with the rest of the [[List of Fables characters#Civilized Apes (maybe)|"civilized apes"]] that Jack Horner claims to have met.<ref name="JOF36" /> Winnie the Pooh and [[Piglet (Winnie-the-Pooh)|Piglet]] apparently made it to the Farm. Both make an obscure appearance in ''Fables'': In part five of the ''Animal Farm'' story arc, when the foiled revolution threatens to flare up again, Pooh and Piglet appears in two panels, from a distance when [[Boy Blue (Fables)|Boy Blue]] tells everyone to move back, and then from behind in the following panel.<ref>''Fables 10: Animal Farm'', Chapter Five</ref> *'''Prospero's Island'''<ref name="F90">''Fables'' 90: ''Witches'', Chapter Four</ref> – The Island which is the setting of [[William Shakespeare]]'s ''[[the Tempest]]''. It is located in the Homelands version of the '''[[Mediterranean Sea]]'''.<ref name="F90" /> [[List of characters in Fables#Prospero|Prospero]]<ref name="F90" /> and [[List of characters in Fables#Maddy|Sycorax]]<ref>''Fables'' 88: ''Witches'', Chapter Two</ref> are members of Fabletown's 13th Floor of magicians and spellcasters. *'''The Great Wiggly River''' – The river in the fable of ''[[The Scorpion and the Frog]]''. Mentioned by Ollikandar Strikeswift, brother of the scorpion in the story, during Mr. Brump the Goblin's trial.<ref>''Fables'' 93: ''Out to the Ball Game'', Part 2 of 2</ref> *'''Harvest Town''' – The town where "the Janky Man" was boxed away.<ref name="F86" /> *'''Sarukan''' – [[List of Fables characters#The New Jack Frost – "Jack Two" or "Jack Too"|"Jack Frost Two"]] was involved in an incident there while working as a hero-for hire.<ref name="JOF46">''Jack of Fables 46: The Ultimate Jack of Fables Story'', part one</ref> *The '''Shifting Worlds''' – Jack Frost Two spent time there while working as a hero-for hire.<ref name="JOF46" /> *The '''Winterlace Floating Worlds''' – Jack Frost Two was involved in an incident there, which ended in a fiasco.<ref name="JOF46" /> *'''Balthador's Gate''' – Jack Frost Two was involved in an incident there while working as a hero-for hire.<ref name="JOF46" /> *'''Planet Seventy-Two''' – Home of the "march wyrm".<ref name="JOF48">''Jack of Fables'' 48: ''The Ultimate Jack of Fables Story'', part three</ref> *'''[[Kansas]]''' – Referred to in ''Cinderella: Fables Are Forever''. The former home of [[List of Fables characters#Dorothy Gale|Dorothy Gale]]<ref name="CF" /> Kansas is presumably located in [[Homelands (Fables)#Americana|Americana]], the Fable version of America. *'''The [[Great Wall]]''' – Referred to in ''Cinderella: Fables Are Forever''.<ref name="CF" /> *'''The Homeland of the North'''<ref name="F111" /> – The [[List of Fables characters#The North Wind|North Wind]]'s own realm of elemental ice and wind.<ref>''Fables'' 106: ''Super Team'', Chapter Five</ref> Not many people can get there, as few know where it is or are able to survive the journey.<ref name="F111" /> *'''Avon Valley''' – Referred to in the story ''In Those Days''.<ref name="F113">''Fables'' 113: ''In those Days''</ref> *'''Seppantyre''' – The city that [[List of Fables characters#Briar Rose|Briar Rose]] is from, located in a "bright and beautiful" land.<ref name="Fairest2">''Fairest'' 02: ''Wide Awake'', Chapter Two</ref> *The '''Twilight Lands''' – Inhabited by the [[fairy godmother]]s from the tale of ''[[Sleeping Beauty]]'', as well as Hadeon the Destroyer, the [[wicked fairy godmother|evil fairy]], who ruled the realm's darkest corners.<ref>''Fairest'' 03: ''Wide Awake'', Chapter Three</ref> *The '''Silver Pool''' – Where a knight, if he is noble and chaste, can be healed of any injury.<ref name="Fairest2" /> *'''Kreese''' – Inhabited by a six-headed lion.<ref name="Fairest2" /> *The '''Deep Night Hollow''' – Where every nightmare is caged and tamed.<ref name="Fairest2" /> *The '''Forest of Ghosts''' – Holds the key to unlock the "seven secrets of the Silent Mountain".<ref name="Fairest2" /> *The '''Silent Mountain''' – The mountain of the "seven secrets".<ref name="Fairest2" /> *The '''Forest of Dire Blight''' – The place where Hadeon the Destroyer dwelled.<ref name="Fairest2" /> *'''Morencaire''' – Referred to in the ''Fairest'' story arc ''Wide Awake''.<ref>''Fairest'' 06: ''Wide Awake'', Chapter Six</ref> *The '''Edge of the World''' – From the archaic model of the [[Flat Earth]]. [[List of Fables characters#Rapunzel/Okiku|Rapunzel]] once sailed off the Edge of the World, and washed up on the shores of the Hidden Kingdom.<ref name="F9" /> *The '''[[Labyrinth]]''' – From the tale of the [[Minotaur]]. During Rapunzel's quest for her lost daughters, she entered the labyrinth and slew the Minotaur.<ref name="Fairest10" /> *The '''Floating Cities of Dabb''' – [[List of Fables characters#Bufkin|Bufkin]] liberated the slaves there during his many adventures.<ref>''Fables'' 124: ''After''</ref> *'''Karth''' – Referred to in the ''Camelot'' story arc.<ref name="Fables137" /> *The '''[[North Pole]]''' – The real version, where [[List of Fables characters (The Homelands)#Santa Claus|Santa Claus]] lives.<ref name="Fables137" />
== Minor lands == *'''[[Boxen (C. S. Lewis)|Boxen]]'''<ref name="LC" /> – The land invented by [[C.S. Lewis]] and his brother Warren when they were children, as described in his memoir ''Surprised by Joy''.<ref>''Surprised by Joy''; C.S. Lewis; {{ISBN|0-00-628083-8}}</ref> *'''Ruby Lake'''<ref name="LC" /> *'''Oakcourt'''<ref name="LC" /> *'''Hollyfield'''<ref name="LC" /> *'''Oak Hollows''' – This place had the gateway that John Barleycorn and Arrow came through.<ref name="F18" /> *'''Skold''' – Minor land that is a link between Kardan and the Rus. This is where [[Boy Blue (Fables)|Boy Blue]] fought and killed a [[dragon]].<ref name="F37" /> *'''Vesteri'''<ref name="F37" /> *'''Kardan''' – Minor land linked to Skold.<ref name="F37" /> *'''Karse'''<ref>''Fables 44: ''Arabian Nights (and Days)'', Chapter Three</ref> – Possibly the Karse from ''[[Exile's Honor]]''. *'''Skribnutch'''<ref>''Fables'' 55: ''Sons of Empire'', Part Four</ref> *'''Ynnes'''<ref>''Fables'' 68: ''The Good Prince'', Chapter Eight</ref> *'''Kurrewyn'''<ref>''Fables'' 74: ''War and Pieces'', Chapter Two</ref> *'''Tiabrut''' – This is the world where [[List of Fables characters#Mister Dark|Mr. Dark]] was imprisoned.<ref>''Fables'' 77: ''The Dark Ages'', Chapter One</ref> *'''[[Levant]]''' – [[List of Fables characters#Other Literals|Prose Page]] spent years there during her quest for knowledge in the Homelands.<ref name="JOF32" /> *'''[[Alexandria]]''' – Prose Page spent a decade there studying.<ref name="JOF32" /> *'''Aldara Quoor'''<ref name="JOF46" /> *'''Onyx'''<ref name="JOF46" /> *'''Stellarholm'''<ref>''Jack of Fables'' 47: ''The Ultimate Jack of Fables Story'', part two</ref> *'''Antrigonet'''<ref name="JOF48" /> *'''[[Kingdom of Aragon|Aragon]]''' – A mythical version of [[Spain]] and possibly [[Portugal]].<ref name="F99" /> Aragon deriving from the [[Kingdom of Aragon]]. *'''Fryslân''' – A mythical version of combined [[Friesland]] and [[the Netherlands]]<ref name="F99" /> *'''[[Bilbao]]''' – The mythical [[Basque Country (greater region)|Basque Country]],<ref name="F99" /> Bilbao referring to its capital. *'''[[Brittany|Bretagne]]''' – A mythical version of [[Brittany]].<ref name="F99" /> *'''Gascogne''' – A mythical version of [[Gascony]].<ref name="F99" /> *'''Septimanie''' – A mythical version of [[Septimania]].<ref name="F99" /> *'''Bourgogne''' – A mythical version of [[Burgundy (region)|Burgundy]]<ref name="F99" /> *'''[[Aquitaine]]''' – A mythical version of Aquitaine that, in contrast to its mundane counterpart, covers the mainland of [[France]].<ref name="F99" /> *'''Kärnten''' – A mythical version of combined [[Slovenia]], [[Bosnia]] and [[Croatia]].<ref name="F99" /> Kärnten deriving from [[Duchy of Carinthia|Carinthia]]. *'''Lotharin''' – A mythical version of combined [[Luxembourg]] and [[Belgium]].<ref name="F99" /> Lotharin deriving from [[Lotharingia]]. *'''Scanda''' – The land of which [[Lindworm|Prince Lindworm]] is ruler of.<ref>''Fables'' 107: ''Waking Beauty''</ref> *'''Westermark''' – The land that [[List of Fables characters#Mr. Kadabra|Mister Kadabra]] was a lord of.<ref name="F113" /> *'''[[Saint George and the Dragon#Silene|Silene]]''' – The homeworld of [[Saint George]].<ref>''Fairest'' 07: ''Lamia''</ref> *'''[[Lemuria (continent)|Lemuria]]'''<ref>''Fables'' 128: ''Snow White'', Chapter Four</ref> *'''Cannondale''' – Where Mr. Brump the [[goblin]] is from.<ref name="Fables137" /> *'''Eastermouse''' – Where Mr. Brump is also from.<ref name="Fables137" /> *'''Dunhollow''' – The homeland of Lady [[Medb|Maeve]].<ref name="Fables137" /> *'''Hybernia''' – A tiny Fable homeland, invaded by [[Baobhan sith]] and the [[Cù Sìth|Cu sith]] from [[Scottish mythology]].<ref>''Fables'' 139: ''The Boys in the Band'', Part 1 of 2</ref>
The Homelands version of [[China]] is referred to, but not named, in ''Cinderella: Fables are Forever'', which refers to [[Qin Dynasty|the empire]] from the [[Chinese folklore|Chinese folktale]] about [[Lady Meng Jiang|Meng Chiang-Nu]].<ref name="CF" />
== Americana == Another land of interest is Americana, the Fable version of America, appearing mainly in the ''[[Jack of Fables]]'' series.
Large areas in Americana include: * '''The Colonies''' – The states of [[New England]].<ref name="JOF9">''Jack of Fables'' 9: ''Jack of Hearts'', Part Four</ref> * '''Antebellum''' – The South.<ref name="JOF9" /> * '''Lone Star''' – The state of [[Texas]].<ref name="JOF9" /> * '''Steamboat''' – The [[Mississippi River]] area.<ref name="JOF9" /> * '''Gangland''' – The [[Chicago]] area during the 1920s.<ref name="JOF9" /> * '''The Frontier''' – covering [[Kansas]], [[Nebraska]], and the [[Dakotas]].<ref name="JOF9" /> * '''Idyll''' – The [[Appalachian Mountains]] area during the 1950s.<ref name="JOF9" /> * '''The West''' – covering the [[Rocky Mountains]] area.<ref name="JOF9" /> * '''The Great White North''' – [[Canada]] and [[The Arctic]].<ref name="JOF19">''Jack of Fables'' 19: ''Americana'', Part Three</ref>
Significant places in Americana are '''[[New York City|Big City]]'''<ref name="JOF9" /><ref name="JOF19" /> and '''[[Salem Witch Trials|Salem]]''' located in the Colonies,<ref name="JOF19" /> '''Steamboat City''' located in Steamboat,<ref name="JOF19" /> '''[[Speakeasy]]''' located in Gangland,<ref name="JOF19" /> '''[[the Grand Canyon]]''' created by [[List of Fables characters#Paul Bunyan and Babe the Blue Ox|Paul Bunyan]]<ref>''Jack of Fables'' 12: ''The Pad Prince'', Part One</ref> and unnamed cities in Lone Star,<ref name="JOF19" /> The Frontier<ref name="JOF19" /> and the Great White North.<ref name="JOF19" /> '''[[Kansas]]''' is referred to in ''Cinderella: Fables Are Forever'' and was the former home of [[List of Fables characters#Dorothy Gale|Dorothy Gale]]<ref name="CF" />
As could be expected from the Homelands, things are not so normal as they should be. The Idyll area seems to be populated entirely by zombies, all being loyal to the Bookburner (who is the head librarian of Americana, the library being located in Idyll),<ref>''Jack of Fables'' 18: ''Americana'', Part Two</ref> while the Great White North seems to represent how America views Canada and Alaska, as it is very clean, [[ice hockey]] being the biggest form of amusement and, according to Jack, having horrible bacon.<ref name="JOF19" />
Untouched by The Adversary's forces, Americana possesses advanced technology compared with the conquered European worlds where the absence of modern arms is crucial to sustain the ruling system. Vehicles and appliances seen are cars from the 1920s, steamtrains, various firearms and even modern household appliances.<ref name="JOF19" /><ref>''Jack of Fables'' 20: ''Americana'', Part Four</ref> Besides, the only known way to enter Americana is by dressing as a vagrant and jumping on a train.<ref>''Jack of Fables'' 17: ''Americana'', Part One</ref>
It is also quite possible that other areas are near or on Americana that resemble ancient Mesoamerica or Latin America.

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = International Campaign to Ban Landmines | pronounce = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | named_after = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | logo = International Campaign to Ban Landmines Logo.svg | logo_size = 200px | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map2 = | map2_size = | map2_alt = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = ICBL | formation = {{start date and age|1992|10|}} | founder = [[Jody Williams]] | founding_location = [[New York City|New York]], USA | type = [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]] | status = [[Nonprofit organization|Nonprofit]] | purpose = Working for a world free of antipersonnel landmines and cluster munitions | headquarters = [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]] | coords = {{coord|46.22|6.14|display=inline, title}} | region = Worldwide | methods = Public awareness, publications and advocating at national, regional and international levels | fields = [[Disarmament]] of [[anti-personnel mine|anti-personnel mines]] | leader_title = | leader_name = | affiliations = | website = [http://www.icbl.org/en-gb/home.aspx www.icbl.org] | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }}
[[File:Friedensnobelpreisverleihung Internationale Kampagne für das Verbot von Landminen 1997.JPG|thumb|right|The Campaign receiving the 1997 [[Nobel Peace Prize]]]]
The '''International Campaign to Ban Landmines''' ('''ICBL''') is a coalition of [[non-governmental organization]]s whose stated objective is a world free of [[anti-personnel mine]]s and [[cluster munition]]s, where mine and cluster munitions survivors see their rights respected and can lead fulfilling lives.
The coalition was formed in 1992 when six organisations with similar interests (France-based [[Handicap International]], Germany-based [[Medico International]], UK-based [[Mines Advisory Group]], and US-based [[Physicians for Human Rights]] and [[Vietnam Veterans of America Foundation]]) agreed to cooperate on their common goal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icbl.org/en-gb/news-and-events/news/2012/20-years-in-the-life-of-a-nobel-peace-prizewinning.aspx|title=20 years in the life of a Nobel Peace Prizewinning campaign|website=ICBL website|accessdate=10 November 2018|quote=1992: (...) Six NGOs (HI, HRW, MI, MAG, PHR, and VVAF) meet in New York and agree to coordinate campaigning efforts}}</ref> The campaign has since grown and spread to become a network with active members in some 100 countries – including groups working on women, children, veterans, religious groups, the environment, human rights, arms control, peace and development—working locally, nationally and internationally to eradicate antipersonnel landmines.A prominent supporter was [[Diana, Princess of Wales]].
The organization and its founding coordinator, [[Jody Williams]], jointly received the 1997 [[Nobel Peace Prize]] for their efforts to bring about the [[Mine Ban Treaty]] (Ottawa Treaty). The signature of this treaty (which bans the use, production, stockpiling, and transfer of anti-personnel mines) is seen as the campaign's greatest success. The prize was received on the organisation's behalf by its co-founder, [[Rae McGrath]] of the Mines Advisory Group and by Tunn Channareth, a Cambodian mine victim and ICBL activist.
The ICBL monitors the global mine and cluster munition situation (through Landmine and Cluster Munition Monitor, its research and monitoring arm), and conducts advocacy activities, lobbying for implementation and universalization of the Mine Ban Treaty, humanitarian mine action programs geared toward the needs of mine-affected communities, support for landmine survivors, their families and their communities, and a stop to the production, use and transfer of landmines, including by non-State armed groups. The ICBL participates in the periodical meetings of the Mine Ban Treaty process, urges states not parties to the treaty to join and non-state armed groups to respect the mine ban norm, condemns mine use and promotes public awareness and debate on the mine issue, organizing events and generating media attention.
==Organizational structure==
In 2011, the International Campaign to Ban Landmines (ICBL) and [[Cluster Munition Coalition]] (CMC) merged into one unified structure, now known as the [[ICBL-CMC]], in order to realize operational efficiencies and reinforce complementary work. The ICBL and the CMC campaigns remain separate and continue to remind governments of their commitments to implement and promote both treaties. Landmine and Cluster Munition Monitor continues its unique civil society monitoring program on the humanitarian and developmental consequences of landmines, cluster munitions, and explosive remnants of war.
The activities of the ICBL-CMC are supported by a Governance Board representative of various elements of the ICBL that provides strategic, financial and human resources oversight. An Advisory Committee provides more regular input to staff and the working of the campaign. Four ambassadors serve as campaign representatives at speaking events and other conferences worldwide. They include [[Jody Williams]], Tun Channareth (Cambodian landmine survivor), Song Kosal (Cambodian landmine survivor), and Margaret Arech Orech (Ugandan landmine survivor and founder of [[Uganda Landmine Survivors Association|Ugandan Landmine Survivors Association]]). Currently, the ICBL has 14 staff members based in Geneva (the central office), Lyon, Paris, and Ottawa. Additionally, the ICBL-CMC hosts several interns each year.
==Mine Ban Treaty== {{main|Ottawa Treaty}} The [[Mine Ban Treaty]], or the [[Ottawa Treaty]], is the international agreement that bans [[anti-personnel mine]]s. Officially entitled ''The Convention on the Prohibition, Use, Stockpiling, Production and Transfer of Antipersonnel Mines and on Their Destruction'', the treaty is sometimes referred to as the [[Ottawa Treaty|Ottawa Convention]]. The Mine Ban Treaty was adopted in Oslo, Norway, in September 1997 and signed by 122 States in Ottawa, Canada, on 3 December 1997. As of March 2018, there were 164 States Parties to the Ottawa Treaty.
The mine ban treaty suggest several agendas to member states:
# Never use antipersonnel mines, nor to "develop, produce, otherwise acquire, stockpile, retain or transfer" them # Destroy mines in their stockpiles within four years # Clear mined areas in their territory within 10 years # In mine-affected countries, conduct mine risk education and ensure that mine survivors, their families and communities receive comprehensive assistance # Offer assistance to other States Parties, for example in providing for survivors or contributing to clearance programs # Adopt national implementation measures (such as national legislation) in order to ensure that the terms of the treaty are upheld in their territory
==Landmine and Cluster Munition Monitor== [http://www.the-monitor.org Landmine and Cluster Munition Monitor] is the ICBL-CMC's research and monitoring arm. It is the ''de facto'' monitoring regime for the Mine Ban Treaty and the [[Convention on Cluster Munitions]] of 2008. It monitors and reports on States Parties' implementation of and compliance with the Mine Ban Treaty and the Convention on Cluster Munitions, and more generally, it assesses the problems caused by landmines, cluster munitions, and other explosive remnants of war (ERW). The Monitor represents the first time that NGOs have come together in a coordinated, systematic, and sustained way to monitor humanitarian law or disarmament treaties, and to regularly document progress and problems, thereby successfully putting into practice the concept of civil society-based verification. Since its creation in 1998, Monitor research has been carried out by a global network of primarily in-country researchers, most of them ICBL-CMC campaigners, and all content undergoes rigorous editing by the Monitor's Editorial Team prior to publication.
==See also== *[[Mines Advisory Group]] *[[Geneva Call]], an [[NGO]] inspired by the ICBL that focuses on [[violent non-state actor|non-state actors]] *[[Ottawa Treaty]] (''Mine Ban Treaty'') *[[Swiss Foundation for Mine Action]] *[[Mine clearance agencies]] *[[Demining]] *[[Land mine]] *[[Anti-personnel mine]] *[[Aki Ra]], an anti-mining activist *[[Ban Advocates]] Voice from communities affected by cluster munitions *[[Manitoba Campaign to Ban Landmines]] *[[International Coalition to Ban Uranium Weapons]] *[[List of anti-war organizations]] *[[List of peace activists]]
==References== <references/> * [https://www.un.org/Depts/mine/UNDocs/ban_trty.htm UN Mine ban treaty text]
==External links== * [http://www.icbl.org International Campaign to Ban Landmines] (official website) * [http://www.the-monitor.org/ Landmine and Cluster Munition Monitor] * [http://www.maginternational.org Mines Advisory Group] * [[Ken Rutherford (scientist)|Ken Rutherford]], [https://www.amazon.com/Disarming-States-International-Movement-Landmines/dp/0313393966/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1298991883&sr=1-1 ''Disarming States: The International Movement to Ban Landmines,'' (March, 2011)]

The '''Laietani''' were an ancient [[Iberians|Iberian]] (Pre-[[Ancient Rome|Roman]]) people of the [[Iberian peninsula]] (the Roman [[Hispania]]). They inhabited the area occupied by the city of [[Barcelona]]. One of the main thoroughfares of the city, [[Via Laietana]], is named after the Laietani. They are believed to have spoken an [[Iberian language]].
The Laietani minted their own coins, which bore the inscription ''laiesken'' in [[northeastern Iberian script]] that is interpreted in the [[Iberian language]] as a self-reference to the ethnic name of that people: from the Laietani or from those of ''Laie''.
==Gallery== <gallery perrow="5"> File:Catalonia Badalona MuseuDeBadalona EstelaFunerariaIberica.JPG|Funerary [[stele]] from [[Badalona]] File:Poblat ibèric Puig Castellar.jpg|Ruins of the Puig Castellar Iberian village, [[Santa Coloma de Gramanet]] File:Penya del Moro Plaqueta de plom Inscripció.jpg|Inscribed lead plates from the Iberian archaeological site [[Penya del Moro]], [[Sant Just Desvern]] File:PoblatIbericCanOliver1.jpg|Vestiges of iberian archaeological site [[Ca n'Oliver Iberian Settlement and Museum]], [[Cerdanyola del Vallès]] </gallery>
